conclusion: The car starts from rest, and the task is to calculate the distance traveled in 60 seconds using the acceleration-time graph.

The acceleration-time graph shows: (1) From 0 to 10 seconds: Constant acceleration of 2 m/s², (2) From 10 to 40 seconds: Zero acceleration (constant velocity), (3) From 40 to 60 seconds: Constant acceleration of -1 m/s² (deceleration).
The velocity function is determined by integrating acceleration, starting with initial velocity v_0 = 0 m/s.
For 0 ≤ t ≤ 10 seconds, v(t) = 2t. At t = 10, v = 20 m/s.
For 10 ≤ t ≤ 40 seconds, acceleration is 0, so velocity remains constant at 20 m/s.
For 40 ≤ t ≤ 60 seconds, v(t) = -t + 60. At t = 40, v = 20 m/s.
The position function is determined by integrating velocity, starting with initial position s_0 = 0.
For 0 ≤ t ≤ 10 seconds, s(t) = t². At t = 10, s = 100 meters.
For 10 ≤ t ≤ 40 seconds, s(t) = 20t - 100. At t = 40, s = 700 meters.
For 40 ≤ t ≤ 60 seconds, s(t) = -t²/2 + 60t - 900. At t = 60, s = 900 meters.
The total distance traveled by the car within 60 seconds is 900 meters.
